componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Altria Globe 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Sarah Knakmuhs, Vice President, Investor Relations of Altria Client Services. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2016 second quarter and first half business results. Earlier today, we issued a press rel
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2016 second quarter and first half business results. 
Earlier today, we issued a press release providing provined these results, which is available on our website at altria.com or through the Altria's investor app. 
During the call today, unless otherwise stated, we're comparing results to the same period in 2015. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review these Forward-looking and Cautionary statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. Future dividend payments and share repurchases remain subject to the discretion of Altria's board. The timing of sharing repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. 
Altria reports its financial results in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both the reported an adjusted basis, which excludes items that effects the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release. Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. jAltria group delivered strong 2016 second quarter and first half results growing adjusted diluted earnings per share by 9.5% in the second quarter and by nearly 11% for the first half. Our c
componenttext:
Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. jAltria group delivered strong 2016 second quarter and first half results growing adjusted diluted earnings per share by 9.5% in the second quarter and by nearly 11% for the first half. 
Our core tobacco businesses continued to produce very strong results, with yet another solid quarter of income and retail share performance. Marlboro match the record retail sale in the first half last year and Copenhagen and Skoal produced excellent share results on a combined basis. And we continued to reward our shareholders paying out more than $2.2 billion in dividends to shareholders thus far in 2016. 
So here are some of the operating highlights from the quarter and the first half. The Smokeable Product segment continued to produce excellent results. Despite difficult year-over-year comparisons, it grew adjusted operating company's income by 4.5% the second quarter and nearly 7% for the first half. You'll recall that last year the Smokable segment grew adjusted OCI by nearly 16% in the second quarter and over 14% for the first half. This growth in 2015 benefited from higher reported volumes at PM USA, driven by stable industrial volume and a trade inventory build influenced by upcoming cigarette exercise tax increases.  
In the second quarter of 2016, the trade depleted inventory levels. So when adjusted for these inventory movements, PM USA estimates it's second quarter cigarette volume declined 3%, in line with PM USA's estimate for the total industry declined rate. For the half, PM USA estimates that it's adjusted cigarette volume declined 1.5% in line with the industry. 
For the first half of 2016, Marlboro's retail share was unchanged at 44.1%, matching its record share levels at a year ago. Marlboro second quarter retail share also was 44.1%, down 1/10th of a point form the year ago period. We are extremely pleased with the smokable segments performance in both the second quarter and first half of 2016. 
Our smokeless products segment continued to deliver excellent income performance, robust volumes and strong share growth on Copenhagen and Skoal combine.  
USSTC grew adjusted OCI by nearly 14% in the second quarter and more than 15% for the first half. USSTC estimates that it's volume after adjusting for trade inventory movements and other factors grew approximately 5% in the second quarter and 4% for the first half, while estimated smokeless industry volume grew approximately 3% for the past 6 months. 
Copenhagen and Skoal increase their combined retail share by 1.5 points in the second quarter and by 9/10th of a share point for the first half. Copenhagen's retail share gained nearly 3 points in the quarter, benefiting from the first full quarter of Copenhagen national expansion at retail.  Copenhagen has performed very well, bringing excitement to the brand for both adult dippers and for the trade. 
Skoal's retail share declined 1.3 points in the second quarter, reflecting in part USSTC's portfolio strategy to invest behind Copenhagen and expand Copenhagen Mint. And as you know, part of USSTC strategy is to grow the combined share of Copenhagen and Skoal. 
In innovative tobacco Nu Mark continuous to invest with discipline in developing a portfolio of products to meet the evolving preferences of adulst tobacco consumers. In e-vapor, market results for MarkTen Xl remain encouraging, as Nu Mark has now distributed the branded into stores, representing approximately 50% of e-vapor category volume in mainstream retail channels including c-stores. 
On the heated tobacco platform, our work with Philip Morris International on it's FDA applications, where premarket authorization and a modified risk tobacco product destination remains on plan, and we're making excellent progress on commercialization strategies for the U.S. market. 
As you know, in May, the FDA published its final deeming regulation, expanding it's regulatory authority to all tobacco products including cigars and e-vapor. We believe we're well-prepared for these regulations and Nu Mark and Middleton are working now to comply with them. Our company is also continued to engage with the FDA and other stakeholders to advocate for changes to the regulations, where we believe appropriate. 
So in summary, we're very pleased with our first half performance. Based on these results and our expectation that our businesses will deliver solid results over the balance of 2016, we now expect to deliver 2016 adjusted diluted earnings per share in a range of $3.01 to $3.07, representing a growth rate of 7.5% to 9.5% from our 2015 adjusted diluted EPS base of $2.80.  As a reminder, this guidance does not include any impact from the proposed AB InBev, SABMiller business combination, as the transaction remains subject to certain approvals and the closing date has not yet been determined. 
Speaking of our beer investment, we're pleased with the significant progress AB InBev has made, securing regulatory clearances. AB InBev has announced that it has obtained approval in 22 jurisdictions, including approvals in the United States, North America, Asia Pacific, Africa, Europe and Latin America. And AB InBev continues to pursue the remaining regulatory clearances that are necessary to close the transaction. 
In addition, as you know, on July 26, AB InBev announced its revised and final offer to SABMiller. This offer among other things would increase the pretax cash that Altria expects to receive to $3 billion from the previously estimated $2.5 billion. The other material terms related to Altria remain the same. 
Internally, our teams are preparing to transition our investment from SABMiller to the new combined entity. One such area of preparation is coordinating how our accounting teams will share information. And through this preportion, we now expect a timing difference between how we currently reported results for our SABMiller investment and how we'll report for our investment in the new combined company. 
Once the proposed transaction closes, we expect to record our share of results from the new company on a 1 quarter lag. will provide you with more details on his remarks. We remain excited about the proposed transaction and look forward to supporting the combination of these 2 great companies. Now I'll turn things over to Billy for more detail on our performance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with some more color on the smokable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.6 percentage points in the second quarter to over 50%, primarily driven by higher net pricing and lower SG&A cos
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with some more color on the smokable product segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.6 percentage points in the second quarter to over 50%, primarily driven by higher net pricing and lower SG&A cost, partially offset by higher resolution expenses.  For the first half, adjusted OCI margins in this segment expended 2.2 points to 49.2%, primarily driven by the same factors. 
PM USA's reported domestic cigarette shipment volume declined 5% in the second quarter, primarily driven by the industry rate of decline and trade inventory moments. In the second quarter of last year, the trade build inventory, ahead of excise tax increases in several states, that went into affect in the next quarter. For the first half PM USA's reported shipment volumes declined 2.1%. 
At retail, PM USA's overall share was unchanged in the second quarter and grew 1/10th of a point for the first half. 
In cigars, higher shipment volume contributed the smokeable products segments performance in both periods. Middleton grew Black & Mild's volumes by 7.5% in the quarter and nearly 8% for the first half  by focusing on the brand strength in the more profitable segment. 
In the smokeless product segment, adjusted OCI margins expanded in the second quarter by nearly 3 percentage points to 69.3% and by 2.6 percentage points to 67.5% for the first half, primarily driven by higher net pricing, partially offset by mix, due to higher popular pricing product volume. 
This smokeless segments reported shipment volumes increased 4.3% in the second quarter and 6% for the first half of 2016, primarily driven by the industry's rate of growth and retail share gains. 
In wine, Ste. Michelle continue to deliver strong results by growing volume of it's premier wines. During this second quarter and first half, Ste. Michelle grew adjusted OCI by nearly 6% and 5% respectively.  Ste. Michelle's reported wine shipment volumes grew more than 3% in the second quarter and 5.5% for the first half. 
Altria recorded reported equity earnings from it's SABMiller investment of $199 million in the second quarter and $265 million for the first half. 
with some more information on the accounting of our beer investment that Marty mentioned. For context, Altria currently records results for it's SABMiller investment concurrent with Altria's reporting calendar. Because new results will not be available to us in time to report them in the current period, we expect to report our share of results using a 1 quarter lag. This means that after the transaction closes, there will be a one-time 3-month transition, with no earnings from our equity earnings in Newco are recorded in our income income statement. For example, Altair share of Newco's results in the quarter in which the transaction closes will be recorded in the subsequent quarter.  The precise periods affected will depend on when the transaction closes. 
It's important to understand that this lag will not affect our cash flows or quarterly dividends per share, that we do expect to impact our year-over-year comparability of our reported and adjusted diluted EPS in the short term and could also affect 2016 adjusted diluted EPS guidance.  As noted in our earnings release, our guidance does not yet include the impact of the expected lag, because the transaction remains subject to certain approvals and the closing date has not yet been determined. 
That wraps our results. Marty and I will take your question. While the calls are being compiled, I'll direct your attention to altria.com. Along with today's earnings release, for your reference, we posted usual list of quarterly metrics, including pricing, inventory and other housekeeping items. Operator, do we have any questions?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chris. Listen, I don't -- we don't see anything in the quarter that causes us to call it out for you. I do think it's consistent with what we've said and you and others I think have said over time that you'd expect for the long-term trends to revert
componenttext: Sure, Chris. Listen, I don't -- we don't see anything in the quarter that causes us to call it out for you. I do think it's consistent with what we've said and you and others I think have said over time that you'd expect for the long-term trends to revert back to their trend line. If you look at '15, we ended the year up a 0.5, the quarter before was down a 0.5 and now for the year -- so for, the first half were down about 1.5. So 1.5 obviously is lower than the long-term trend line, but it's higher than it was in 2015 when we had these interruptions because of the gas prices and all. So I think it's consistent with how we see it Chris, which is just slowly reverting back to the long-term trend line.

componenttext: This is Miller on for Nik. Just a one question for you guys. How does Altria think about within the context of the new and the FDA's more stringent view on substantial equivalents? And more specifically there, should we assume innovation will be delayed from hitting the market? And if so, how should we think about volumes in that context?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for the question. For a thorough summary, I think of our views, I might refer you you and others to the comments that we've filed. I'm sure you've seen them, in which we picked up this point. We do think that innovation in the category is imp
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for the question. For a thorough summary, I think of our views, I might refer you you and others to the comments that we've filed. I'm sure you've seen them, in which we picked up this point. We do think that innovation in the category is important. We're working very hard on our innovation system and our on innovative products for the adult tobacco consumer, and we believe that it would be good public policy for the FDA to encourage. Our comments had pointed out to the FDA, that some of what's in the deeming regulations does not seem to be particularly friendly to that concept. And so we continue -- I think we mentioned in our remarks this morning, we're both complying with the regs and we're trying to influence and advocate where we think the regs could be improved. And I think in the area of innovation, I think you picked up on an area where they could be improved. I think it's too soon to tell what the effect on volumes. I hope that's helpful to you?

componenttext: Sure. Judy, basically, the way we approach estimating that -- the industry decline is, we take that total shipments that are reported, and then we look at inventory movements, and we adjust for those inventory moments so that we get towards a more true consumption offtake to your point. componenttext: I had -- I guess, I just had 2 questions on -- follow-up questions on deeming. I guess first, this may be pretty straightforward, but could you give us a reminder where you stand on the challenge that you've filed to the descriptor brand included in the cigar deeming portion? Do you have an injunction? Do you have expect to have an inunction by August 8 or would you have additional flexibility to continue marketing your products beyond that date?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, and pleased to tell you the matter has resolved. So we had objected to that, as you know, on our comments and FDA put it in the deeming relations. We filed suite, and FDA has informed us that they do not at this time intend enforce tha
componenttext: Yes, good question, and pleased to tell you the matter has resolved. So we had objected to that, as you know, on our comments and FDA put it in the deeming relations. We filed suite, and FDA has informed us that they do not at this time intend enforce that in Black & Mild. And in consideration for that, we have withdrawn our law suite. The parties have reserved their rights, but we will continue to use Black & Mild unless something changes.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good to hear. And just another I -- even though the published regulations didn't make any immediate changes in your ability to market products with characterizing flavors, the redline draft that was made public afterward indicated that the FD
componenttext: Okay, that's good to hear. And just another I -- even though the published regulations didn't make any immediate changes in your ability to market products with characterizing flavors, the redline draft that was made public afterward indicated that the FDA had initially intended to take a more rigid position on flavored products and voice some concerns around their on used assumptions. So -- the end outcome was favorable, but I'm just curious how you interpret the implications of the redline draft? And what that mean for their orientation toward menthol going forward?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll have to see going forward. I mean, I think menthol stands on it's merits and I won't repeat what we both know Matt on that. You know the signs on that and when you put it on papers on that. So I'm not sure it has a big effect on menthol. I do t
componenttext: Yes, we'll have to see going forward. I mean, I think menthol stands on it's merits and I won't repeat what we both know Matt on that. You know the signs on that and when you put it on papers on that. So I'm not sure it has a big effect on menthol. I do think that there had been instances, in which some tobacco control have argued to take flavors away from adult tobacco consumers in the name of trying to prevent youth consumption. Our review on that is that there is so much that can be to prevent youth comsumption. Most of which we have worked on and the numbers are trending in the right direction that we wanted to defend the flavors of our adult tobacco consumers who enjoying perfect example, where flavors have been in that category for decades and decades. So we'll have to see how the FDA approaches that, but we think that there are actually very separate issues about youth consumption and flavors.

componenttext: It's for Vivien. After benefiting from a benign exercise tax environment over the last 2 years, I was hoping to get an update on the state excise taxes, given we saw 3 states passed tax increases in the first half the year and have open legislation as well as notable proposed initiatives? How should we think about the outlook for the weighted average over the course of the year?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a little bit information in that -- in the housekeeping, but you're right, we had 3 increases so far in 2016, Louisiana, West Virginia and most recently Pennsylvania. We also had a facing effect a few that the past previously that came into e
componenttext: Yes, we have a little bit information in that -- in the housekeeping, but you're right, we had 3 increases so far in 2016, Louisiana, West Virginia and most recently Pennsylvania. We also had a facing effect a few that the past previously that came into effect in Connecticut, Minnesota and Oregon, if I recall correctly. The weighted average, I think is a $1.56 as we stand, but we will have Pennsylvania coming online obviously after August 1. So we heat up a little bit. It's good question. We continued to resist these. We think there are unfair to adjust tobacco consumers, but state budgets being what they are, we just have to go through this every year. The one that I would recommend that you be watchful of course, California were the ballot has qualified. So that's proposed $2, which would be on the ballot in California in November.

componenttext: Well, we're trying to step into it with discipline. We're trying to go with the business. The stores that we've chosen have good e-vapor business. We have a very good marketplace response. We had a very good consumer response. So we know our strategy date, which is -- we have aspirations to be the long-term leader, but we want to proceed with financial discipline always learning from the consumer, and I'm very pleased with the progress making in that regard. So I would expect more of the same kind of approach.

So do you give a disproportionate amount of R&D resources there or to some extent, I recognize to follow the consumer, but how much can you also try to maybe lead them are but an versus e-vapor and that's at the margin profile, certainly at this moment, and some different competitive dynamics, how do you think about all that? headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a process to do of course, actually, had 2 processes. We have a strategy process and it's tightly linked to our budget process. So our operating company is coming within their plans. We've talked about this previously. We have 1-year plans an
componenttext: Yes, we have a process to do of course, actually, had 2 processes. We have a strategy process and it's tightly linked to our budget process. So our operating company is coming within their plans. We've talked about this previously. We have 1-year plans and 3-year plans and longer-term plans, and they make the case for investment. And then Altria Group decides on how to allocate resources about where the best opportunities lie for our shareholders. And the good news is, all of our operating companies have lots of good ideas. So it's always a good discussion about where best to go, but that's the process we use, Michael. We look at it and then we put our strategy and our budget together for both 1, 3 and longer plans, we try to put the resources where we think the greatest opportunities lie including in margin enhancements.

componenttext: Yes, I think we talked about this when we announced the productive initiative, which is that we do want to make some continuing the investments -- of area of long-term value to the shareholder and clearly an investment in innovative tobacco products, particularly those with a potential to reduced harm are high in our list for investments. So we haven't given much detail below that, not to preempt your next question Michael, but those are the areas, and I think when you think about vapor and other innovative products for consumers, that's a good place to invest for the long-term proposition of both the company and for our consumers.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Have you been able to get any -- have you had an ability to engage with the FDA yet? And have any sense on how receptive they might be to the platform?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we talked about this last time, which is that, I did want to comment in too many particulars about an application that involves obviously PMI because it's a product that they're trying to qualify, but we did talk about the process and the pr
componenttext: Well, I think we talked about this last time, which is that, I did want to comment in too many particulars about an application that involves obviously PMI because it's a product that they're trying to qualify, but we did talk about the process and the process is, there is typically a degree engagement between the manufacturer that's trying to bring that product to market and FDA staff. I think, we talked previously about, for example, you don't want to design and execute clinical trials, which are lengthy and expensive without knowing that the FDA, I think is thinking that you're asking the right question. So I would also point to comments that Director has made publically about  understanding, there is a continuum of harm among tobacco products and that the agency has to be thoughtful about how they encourage manufacturers and consumers to migrate to these kinds of products. So these things aren't done until they're done, but I continue to be optimistic that this is the way forward by bringing innovations to consumers, which maybe reduce harm. It's good idea for everyone.

componenttext: I can try to help you a little bit. I know that we've had this conversation before. There is a desire I know to get onto that. We just don't break them out. I mean, we've had tables in the earnings release, which shows, as much as I think, we're willing to disclose. Look, the way to think about this Bonnie, I think is that overall Marlboro continues to perform terrifically. Because most of our shipments in the cigarette segment are Marlboro, and actually you would expect the volume to track, but we don't report at that level, but Marlboro is doing great. It continues to have as we mentioned, record share if you measured against the half. It's equity is doing great. The Marlboro architecture continues to perform well. If you and I spoken previously about the exciting digital marketing for adult tobacco consumers and we've improved the app even further and we've got exciting promotions on there. So I think the way to think about Marlboro, it is doing exactly what we wanted to do and it is doing it well.

componenttext: Yes, we're working at 2 levels. One is, directly with the consumer obviously because adult consumers once there are age verified can get the apps and participant that way, but another big area for us and we're very grateful for the partnership with our trade partners. Our trade partners are increasingly excited about the ability to use their loyalty programs with our digital marketing and our apps and the like. So many of our trade partners are working with us on that. So we're getting very good on that. I would -- I'd like to say that I think we are ahead on this, and I think our trade thinks we're hard on this and our consumer reception has been nothing short of terrific. So it's very efficient and it's very responsible, and we're reaching the people we want to reach in a responsible of a way, and I think it is the way forward.

componenttext: Yes, we have not made decisions around the $3 billion, but I can't walk you, lets step back from that. And then when we have access cash, you seen us do a multitude of things with that. Certainly, we do share repurchases. You seen us do debt tenders and seen us do debt tender refis. So this being excess cash, we would assess it based on market conditions at the time and make appropriate decisions.

If I can come back to you to the rights, and in particular, 2 questions. First of all, you said you're in conversation about ting to change aspects of them. And I wonder if you could just highlight, what you're to change that you think a realistic chance with the FDA will listen to what you say you change how that approach? 
And the second question is this, Reynolds have said, that they believe based on the continued of risk, seen some very you may take more relaxed approach to premarket approvals for for e-vapor products, then they have done it would seem with cigarettes. And I guess, the relation question to that, do you agree with that? And do you think there will be a different degree of let's say cigars and e-vapor products?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I'll give you an example for first was which is predicate date. We have argued to the FDA and advocated to the FDA as did with many others, that it made little sense to go back and you cigarette of 2007 that probably came into the marketplace a
componenttext:
All right. I'll give you an example for first was which is predicate date. We have argued to the FDA and advocated to the FDA as did with many others, that it made little sense to go back and you cigarette of 2007 that probably came into the marketplace after 2007. So there continues to be a lot of dialogue about that. That is not limited to the FDA, that there is legislated proposal spending. So I think a lot of people think that it would be wise to revisit that portion. We certainly do and you may heard about the conversation we had earlier about encouraging innovation it did for us not seeming to do that. So that is one area. 
With respect to I'm not familiar with the conversation someone else, but I can tell you that it would seem to make sense for premarket approvals, you certainly ought to be taking into account the degree of harm of the product. So cigarettes, as we all know, bear a degree of risk. And while the evidence is not come lately in and it appears that be because they don't burn e-vapor probably has a lower risk. That's of course not taken into account in approving whether they should come into markets. So that would seem a sensible approach. I think that's a development that would be good for consumers and for manufactures and for public.

[Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Sarah Knakmuhs, Vice President, Investor Relations for Altria Client Services. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2016 second quarter and first half business results. Earlier today, we issued a press rel
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2016 second quarter and first half business results. 
Earlier today, we issued a press release providing these results, which is available on our website at altria.com or through the Altria investor app. 
During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we're comparing results to the same period in 2015. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the Forward-looking and Cautionary Statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. 
Future dividend payments and share repurchases remain subject to the discretion of Altria's board. The timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. 
Altria reports its financial results in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported and adjusted basis, which excludes items that affects the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Altria group delivered strong 2016 second quarter and first half results, growing adjusted diluted earnings per share by 9.5% in the second quarter and by nearly 11% for the first half. Our c
componenttext:
Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Altria group delivered strong 2016 second quarter and first half results, growing adjusted diluted earnings per share by 9.5% in the second quarter and by nearly 11% for the first half. 
Our core tobacco businesses continued to produce very strong results, with yet another solid quarter of income and retail share performance. Marlboro matched the record retail share it set in the first half last year, and Copenhagen and Skoal produced excellent share results on a combined basis. And we continued to reward our shareholders, paying out more than $2.2 billion in dividends to shareholders thus far in 2016. 
So here are some of the operating highlights from the quarter and the first half. The smokeable products segment continued to produce excellent results. Despite difficult year-over-year comparisons, it grew adjusted operating company's income by 4.5% in the second quarter and nearly 7% for the first half. You'll recall that last year the smokable segment grew adjusted OCI by nearly 16% in the second quarter and over 14% for the first half. This growth in 2015 benefited from higher reported volumes at PM USA, driven by stable industry volume and a trade inventory build influenced by upcoming cigarette excise tax increases.  
In the second quarter of 2016, the trade depleted inventory levels. So when adjusted for these inventory movements, PM USA estimates its second quarter cigarette volume declined 3%, in line with PM USA's estimate for the total industry declined rate. For the half, PM USA estimates that its adjusted cigarette volume declined 1.5%, in line with the industry. 
For the first half of 2016, Marlboro's retail share was unchanged at 44.1%, matching its record share levels at a year ago. Marlboro second quarter retail share also was 44.1%, down 0.1 point form the year-ago period. We are extremely pleased with the smokable segments performance in both the second quarter and first half of 2016. 
Our smokeless products segment continued to deliver excellent income performance, robust volumes and strong share growth on Copenhagen and Skoal combined.  
USSTC grew adjusted OCI by nearly 14% in the second quarter and more than 15% for the first half. USSTC estimates that its volume, after adjusting for trade inventory movements and other factors, grew approximately 5% in the second quarter and 4% for the first half, while estimated smokeless industry volume grew approximately 3% for the past 6 months. 
Copenhagen and Skoal increased their combined retail share by 1.5 points in the second quarter and by 0.9 share point for the first half. Copenhagen's retail share gained nearly 3 points in the quarter, benefiting from the first full quarter of Copenhagen Mint's national expansion at retail.  Copenhagen Mint has performed extremely well, bringing excitement to the brand for both adult dippers and for the trade. 
Skoal's retail share declined 1.3 points in the second quarter, reflecting in part USSTC's portfolio strategy to invest behind Copenhagen and expand Copenhagen Mint. And as you know, part of USSTC's strategy is to grow the combined share of Copenhagen and Skoal. 
In innovative tobacco products, Nu Mark continues to invest with discipline in developing a portfolio of products to meet the evolving preferences of adult tobacco consumers. In e-vapor, market results for MarkTen XL remain encouraging as Nu Mark has now distributed the brand into stores, representing approximately 50% of e-vapor category volume in mainstream retail channels, including c-stores. 
On the heated tobacco platform, our work with Philip Morris International on its FDA applications, where premarket authorization and a modified risk tobacco product destination remains on plan, and we're making excellent progress on commercialization strategies for the U.S. market. 
As you know, in May, the FDA published its final deeming regulation, expanding it's regulatory authority to all tobacco products, including cigars and e-vapor. We believe we're well-prepared for these regulations and Nu Mark and Middleton are working now to comply with them. Our companies also continued to engage with FDA and other stakeholders to advocate for changes to the regulations where we believe appropriate. 
So in summary, we're very pleased with our first half performance. Based on these results and our expectation that our businesses will deliver solid results over the balance of 2016, we now expect to deliver 2016 adjusted diluted earnings per share in a range of $3.01 to $3.07, representing a growth rate of 7.5% to 9.5% from our 2015 adjusted diluted EPS base of $2.80. As a reminder, this guidance does not include any impact from the proposed AB InBev, SABMiller business combination, as the transaction remains subject to certain approvals and the closing date has not yet been determined. 
Speaking of our beer investment, we're pleased with the significant progress AB InBev has made, securing regulatory clearances. AB InBev has announced that it has obtained approval in 22 jurisdictions, including approvals in the United States, North America, Asia Pacific, Africa, Europe and Latin America. And AB InBev continues to pursue the remaining regulatory clearances that are necessary to close the transaction. 
In addition, as you know, on July 26, AB InBev announced its revised and final offer to SABMiller. This offer, among other things, would increase the pretax cash that Altria expects to receive to $3 billion from the previously estimated $2.5 billion. The other material terms related to Altria remain the same. 
Internally, our teams are preparing to transition our investment from SABMiller to the new combined entity. One such area of preparation is coordinating how our accounting teams will share information. And through this preportion, we now expect a timing difference between how we currently report results for our SABMiller investment and how we'll report for our investment in the new combined company. 
Once the proposed transaction closes, we expect to record our share of results from the new company on a 1-quarter lag. Billy will provide you with more detail in his remarks. We remain excited about the proposed transaction and look forward to supporting the combination of these 2 great companies. 
Now I'll turn things over to Billy for more detail on our performance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with some more color on the smokable products segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.6 percentage points in the second quarter to over 50%, primarily driven by higher net pricing and lower SG&A co
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with some more color on the smokable products segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.6 percentage points in the second quarter to over 50%, primarily driven by higher net pricing and lower SG&A costs, partially offset by higher resolution expenses. For the first half, adjusted OCI margins in the segment expended 2.2 points to 49.2%, primarily driven by the same factors. 
PM USA's reported domestic cigarette shipment volume declined 5% in the second quarter, primarily driven by the industry's rate of decline and trade inventory moments. In the second quarter of last year, the trade built inventory, ahead of excise tax increases in several states that went into affect in the next quarter. For the first half PM USA's reported cigarette shipment volume declined 2.1%. 
At retail, PM USA's overall share was unchanged in the second quarter and grew 0.1point for the first half. 
In cigars, higher shipment volume contributed to the smokeable products segment's performance in both periods. Middleton grew Black & Mild's volume by 7.5% in the quarter and nearly 8% for the first half by focusing on the brand strength in the more profitable tip segment. 
In the smokeless products segment, adjusted OCI margins expanded in the second quarter by nearly 3 percentage points to 69.3% and by 2.6 percentage points to 67.5% for the first half, primarily driven by higher net pricing, partially offset by mix due to higher popular price product volume.  The smokeless segment's reported shipment volumes increased 4.3% in the second quarter and 6% for the first half of 2016, primarily driven by the industry's rate of growth and retail share gains. 
In wine, Ste. Michelle continued to deliver strong results by growing volume of its premium wines. During this second quarter and first half, Ste. Michelle grew adjusted OCI by nearly 6% and 5%, respectively.  Ste. Michelle's reported wine shipment volumes grew more than 3% in the second quarter and 5.5% for the first half. 
Altria recorded reported equity earnings from its SABMiller investment of $199 million in the second quarter and $265 million for the first half. 
So let me close with some more information on the accounting of our beer investment that Marty mentioned. For context, Altria currently records results for its SABMiller investment concurrent with Altria's reporting calendar. Because NewCo's results will not be available to us in time to report them in the concurrent period, we expect to report our share of NewCo's results using a 1-quarter lag. This means that after the transaction closes, there will be a one-time 3-month transition where no earnings from our equity investment in NewCo are recorded in our income statement. For example, Altair's share of NewCo's results in the quarter in which the transaction closes will be recorded in the subsequent quarter. The precise periods affected will depend on when the transaction closes. 
It's important to understand that this lag will not affect our cash flows or quarterly dividends per share, but we do expect it to impact our year-over-year comparability of our reported and adjusted diluted EPS in the short term and could also affect 2016 adjusted diluted EPS guidance. As noted in our earnings release, our guidance does not yet include the impact of the expected lag because the transaction remains subject to certain approvals and the closing date has not yet been determined. 
That wraps our results. Marty and I will now take your question. While the calls are being compiled, I'll direct your attention to altria.com. Along with today's earnings release, for your reference, we've posted our usual list of quarterly metrics, including pricing, inventory and other housekeeping items. 
Operator, do we have any questions?

componenttext: Okay, got you. And then just a question, overall, on the category. Down 3%, a little different from what Reynolds had indicated, but either way, moving back towards more of a normalized rate of decline, I know you don't like to guidance on volumes. So in this quarter, with the gas price down, the consumer is still in better shape, it looked like volume is still weak a little bit sequentially more than I expected. headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chris. Listen, I don't -- we don't see anything in the quarter that causes us to call it out for you. I do think it's consistent with what we've said and you and others I think have said over time that you would expect for the long-term trends to re
componenttext: Sure, Chris. Listen, I don't -- we don't see anything in the quarter that causes us to call it out for you. I do think it's consistent with what we've said and you and others I think have said over time that you would expect for the long-term trends to revert back to their trend line. If you look at '15, we ended the year up 0.5 the quarter before was down 0.5and now for the year, so far, the first half we're down about 1.5. So 1.5 obviously is lower than the long-term trend line, but it's higher than it was in 2015 when we had these interruptions because of the gas prices and all. So I think it's consistent with how we see it Chris, which is it's just slowly reverting back to the long-term trend line.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Russ Miller on for Nik. Just a philosophical question for you guys. How does Altria think about innovation within the context of the new deeming regs and the FDA's more stringent view on substantial equivalents? And more specifically there, should
componenttext: This is Russ Miller on for Nik. Just a philosophical question for you guys. How does Altria think about innovation within the context of the new deeming regs and the FDA's more stringent view on substantial equivalents? And more specifically there, should we assume innovation will be delayed from hitting the market? And if so, how should we think about volumes in that context?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for the question. For a thorough summary, I think of our views, I might refer you and others to the comments that we've filed, I'm sure you've seen them, in which we've picked up this very point. We do think that innovation in the category is
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for the question. For a thorough summary, I think of our views, I might refer you and others to the comments that we've filed, I'm sure you've seen them, in which we've picked up this very point. We do think that innovation in the category is important. We're working very hard on our innovation system and on innovative products for the adult tobacco consumer, and we believe that it would be good public policy for the FDA to encourage that. Our comments have pointed out to the FDA, that some of what's in the deeming regulations does not seem to be particularly friendly to that concept. And so we continue -- I think we mentioned in our remarks this morning, we're both complying with the regs, and we're trying to influence and advocate where we think the regs could be improved. And I think in the area of innovation, I think you picked up on an area where they could be improved. I think it's too soon to tell what the effect will be on volumes. I hope that's helpful to you.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: So I just wanted to clarify the industry volume numbers and understand there may be some differences in how you adjust for inventory adjustment. headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Judy, basically, the way we approach estimating that industry decline is we take total shipments that are reported and then we look at inventory movements and we adjust for those inventory moments so that we get towards a more true consumption offta
componenttext: Sure. Judy, basically, the way we approach estimating that industry decline is we take total shipments that are reported and then we look at inventory movements and we adjust for those inventory moments so that we get towards a more true consumption offtake to your point. And then the only other difference in this period is a calendar day difference. And so those are the major factors that we would adjust for to get to a more consumption offtake.

componenttextpreview: I had -- I guess, I just had 2 questions on -- follow-up questions on deeming. First, this may be pretty straightforward, but could you give us a reminder of where you stand on the challenge that you've filed to the descriptor ban included in the cigar de
componenttext: I had -- I guess, I just had 2 questions on -- follow-up questions on deeming. First, this may be pretty straightforward, but could you give us a reminder of where you stand on the challenge that you've filed to the descriptor ban included in the cigar deeming portion? Do you have an injunction? Do you have expect to have an inunction by August 8 or would you have additional flexibility to continue marketing your products beyond that date?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, and I'm pleased to tell you the matter has resolved. So we had objected to that, as you know, on our comments and FDA put it in the deeming regulations. We filed suit, and FDA has informed us that they do not at this time intend to enf
componenttext: Yes, good question, and I'm pleased to tell you the matter has resolved. So we had objected to that, as you know, on our comments and FDA put it in the deeming regulations. We filed suit, and FDA has informed us that they do not at this time intend to enforce that against Black & Mild. And in consideration for that, we have withdrawn our lawsuit. The parties have reserved their rights, but we will continue to use Black & Mild unless something changes.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good to hear. And just another one, even though the published regulations didn't make any immediate changes in your ability to market products with characterizing flavors. The redline draft that was made public afterward indicated that the FD
componenttext: Okay, that's good to hear. And just another one, even though the published regulations didn't make any immediate changes in your ability to market products with characterizing flavors. The redline draft that was made public afterward indicated that the FDA had initially intended to take a more rigid position on flavored products and voice some concerns around their impact on used consumption. So the end outcome was favorable, but I'm just curious how you interpret the implications of the redline draft and what that might mean for their orientation toward menthol going forward.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll have to see going forward. I mean, I think menthol stands on it's merits, and I won't repeat what we both know, Matt, on that. You know the science on that, and we you put it in our papers on that. So I'm not sure it has a big effect on menthol
componenttext: Yes, we'll have to see going forward. I mean, I think menthol stands on it's merits, and I won't repeat what we both know, Matt, on that. You know the science on that, and we you put it in our papers on that. So I'm not sure it has a big effect on menthol. I do think that there had been instances in which some in tobacco control have argued to take flavors away from adult tobacco consumers in the name of trying to prevent youth consumption. Our view on that is that there is so much that can be done to prevent youth comsumption, most of which we have worked on and the numbers are trending in the right direction that we wanted to defend the flavors for our adult tobacco consumers who have enjoyed the cigar category is a perfect example where flavors have been in that category for decades and decades. So we'll have to see how the FDA approaches that, but we think that there are actually very separate issues about youth consumption and flavors.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Vivien Azer with Cowen & Company.

componenttext: It's Aaron Grey for Vivien. After benefiting from a benign excise tax environment over the last 2 years, I was hoping to get an update on the state excise taxes, given we saw 3 states passed tax increases in the first half of the year and have open legislation as well as notable proposed [indiscernible] initiatives? How should we think about the outlook for the weighted average SET over the course of the year?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a little bit information in that in the housekeeping. But you're right, we had 3 increases so far in 2016, Louisiana, West Virginia and, most recently, Pennsylvania. We also had a phase-in effect of the few were passed previously that came in
componenttext: Yes, we have a little bit information in that in the housekeeping. But you're right, we had 3 increases so far in 2016, Louisiana, West Virginia and, most recently, Pennsylvania. We also had a phase-in effect of the few were passed previously that came into effect, Connecticut, Minnesota and Oregon, if I recall correctly. The weighted average, I think, is $1.56 as we stand, but we will have Pennsylvania coming online obviously after August 1. So we had speed it up a little bit. It's a good question. We continue to resist these. We think they're unfair to adult tobacco consumers, but state budgets being what they are, we just have to go through this every year. The one that I would recommend that you be watchful of, of course, is California were the ballot has qualified. So that's proposed $2, which would be on the ballot in California in November.

componenttext: Well, we're trying to step into it with discipline. We're trying to go where the business is. The stores that we've chosen have good e-vapor business. We had a very good marketplace response. We've had very good consumer response. So you know our strategy there, which is -- we have aspirations to be the long-term leader, but we want to proceed with financial discipline, always learning from the consumer. And I'm very pleased with the progress that MarkTen XL is making in that regard. So I would expect more of the same kind of an approach.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious if you could talk a little bit about how you think about some of resource allocation. Just looking at margins in smokeless now, they're a hair shy in the quarter, at least of 70%. So do you give a disproportionate amount of R&D resources ther
componenttext: Just curious if you could talk a little bit about how you think about some of resource allocation. Just looking at margins in smokeless now, they're a hair shy in the quarter, at least of 70%. So do you give a disproportionate amount of R&D resources there or to some extent I recognize the need to follow the consumer, but how much can you also try to maybe lead them a little bit or -- versus, say, vapor, that's a different margin profile, certainly at least at the moment, and some different competitive dynamics. How do you think about all that? And of course, price is a lever as well, and we saw that in the quarter 2. How do you think about balancing all those to take advantage of the opportunity in that segment?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have a process to do that, of course, actually, have 2 processes. We have a strategy process and it's tightly linked to our budget process. So our operating companies come in with their plans. We've talked about this previously. We have 1-year pla
componenttext: Yes. We have a process to do that, of course, actually, have 2 processes. We have a strategy process and it's tightly linked to our budget process. So our operating companies come in with their plans. We've talked about this previously. We have 1-year plans and 3-year plans and longer-term plans, and they make the case for investment. And then Altria Group decides on how to allocate resources about where the best opportunities lie for our shareholders. And the good news is all of our operating companies have lots of good ideas, so it's always a good discussion about where best to go. But that's the process we use, Michael. We look at it, and then when we put our strategy and our budget together for both 1, 3 and longer plans, we try to put the resources where we think the greatest opportunities lie, including in margin enhancement.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then looking at the other segment and PMCC, your finance assets on the balance sheet certainly have been coming down. Obviously, you've been not investing in that business and essentially unwinding it. Can you give a look ahead at what the traje
componenttext: Okay. And then looking at the other segment and PMCC, your finance assets on the balance sheet certainly have been coming down. Obviously, you've been not investing in that business and essentially unwinding it. Can you give a look ahead at what the trajectory is on that? Certainly, some of these leases have long lives, but you've been doing some sales opportunistically. What do we -- what should we expect for what that contributes near term and maybe medium term?

componenttext: Yes, I think we talked about this when we announced the productivity initiative, which is that we do want to make some continuing investments -- of area of long-term value to the shareholder. And clearly an investment in innovative tobacco products, particularly those with the potential to reduced harm, are high on our list for investments. So we haven't given much detail below that, not to preempt your next question Michael, but those are the areas, and I think when you think about vapor and ICOS and other innovative products for consumers, that's a good place to invest for the long-term proposition of both the company and for our consumers.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we talked about this last time, right, which is that I didn't want to comment too many particulars about an application that involves, obviously, PMI because it's a product that they're trying to qualified. But we did talk about the process,
componenttext: Well, I think we talked about this last time, right, which is that I didn't want to comment too many particulars about an application that involves, obviously, PMI because it's a product that they're trying to qualified. But we did talk about the process, and the process is there is typically a high degree of engagement between the manufacturer that's trying to bring that product to market and the FDA staff. I think we talked previously about, for example, you don't want to design and execute clinical trials, which are lengthy and expensive, without knowing that the FDA, I think, is thinking that you're asking the right questions. So I would also point to comments that Director Zeller has made publicly about understanding that there is a continuum of harm among tobacco products and that the agency has to be thoughtful about how they encourage manufacturers and consumers to migrate to these kinds of products. So these things aren't done until they're done, but I continue to be optimistic that this is the way forward by bringing innovations to consumers, which may reduce harm. It's a good idea for everyone.

componenttext: Bonnie, thanks for the question. Yes, we have not made decisions around the $3 billion, but I can walk you -- let's step back from that. So absent the $3 billion, here's the way we think about allocating our capital, the excess cash. So we think about, of course, dividends first, and that's that 80% dividend target payout ratio. And then when we have the excess cash, you've seen us do a multitude of things with that. Certainly, we do share repurchases. You've seen us do debt tenders, and you've seen us do debt tenders refis. So this being excess cash, we would assess it based on market conditions at the time and make the appropriate decisions.

componenttext: No, I don't think so. Listen, we don't want to sound for a moment arrogant about it, but the business is really performing well. headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can come back to the deeming rights, and in particular, 2 questions. First of all, you said you're in conversation about trying to change aspects of them. And I wonder if you could just highlight what you are most keen to change that you think with a
componenttext: If I can come back to the deeming rights, and in particular, 2 questions. First of all, you said you're in conversation about trying to change aspects of them. And I wonder if you could just highlight what you are most keen to change that you think with a realistic chance that the FDA will listen to what you're saying and actually change how they're approaching deeming. And the second question is this, Reynolds have said that they believe, based on the [indiscernible] continuum of risk, that there seems some ways they may take a more relaxed approach to premarket approvals for e-vapor products than they have done, it would seem, with cigarettes. And I guess, the related question to that is do you agree with that? And do you think there will also be a difference in degree of, let's say, harshness of interpretation of cigars and e-vapor products?

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thanks for the questions. I'll give you an example on your first question which is predicate date. We had argued to the FDA and advocated to the FDA, as did many others, that it made little sense to go back and use a cigarette predicate date of
componenttext: All right, thanks for the questions. I'll give you an example on your first question which is predicate date. We had argued to the FDA and advocated to the FDA, as did many others, that it made little sense to go back and use a cigarette predicate date of 2007 for products that basically came into the marketplace after 2007. So there continues to be a lot of dialogue about that. That is not limited to the FDA, you know that there are legislated proposals pending. And so I think a lot of people think that it would be wise to revisit that question. We certainly do. And you may have heard the conversation we had earlier about encouraging innovation. Using that predicate date, to us, does not seem to do that. So that's one area. With respect to PMTAs, I'm not familiar with the conversation you've referenced with someone else, but I can tell you that it would seem to make sense that, for premarket approvals, you certainly, if you were the regulator, ought to be taking into account the degree of harm of the product. And so cigarettes, as we all know, bear a high degree of risk, and while the evidence is not completely in, it appears to be that because they don't burn, e-vapor probably has a lower risk. That of course ought to be taken into account in approving whether they should come to market. So that would seem to be a sensible approach. I think that's a development that would be good for consumers and for manufactures and for public health.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Can I just come back? I do understand that Congress may change the predicate date. But assuming they don't, do you think there's any realistic chance that a dialog, other than by Congress, or maybe through this occasion, would actually also [indiscernible] to that date?

componenttext: I hope so. Listen, FDA has a job to do. We have found them to be open to listening to reasonable arguments. But at the end of the day, Adam, it's up to them. But we have not found them to be immune from listening to points of view, and hopefully, coming to some reasoned judgment on it, particularly if other stakeholders besides us weigh in on it, as I understand is the case.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Altria Globe 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Sarah Knakmuhs, Vice President, Investor Relations for Altria Client Services. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2016 Second Quarter and First Half Business Results. Earlier today, we issued a press rel
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Billy Gifford, our CFO, to discuss Altria's 2016 Second Quarter and First Half Business Results. 
Earlier today, we issued a press release providing these results, which is available on our website at altria.com or through the Altria investor app. 
During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we're comparing results to the same period in 2015. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the Forward-looking and Cautionary Statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. 
Future dividend payments and share repurchases remain subject to the discretion of Altria's board. The timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. 
Altria reports its financial results in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported and adjusted basis, which excludes items that affects the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Altria group delivered strong 2016 second quarter and first half results, growing adjusted diluted earnings per share by 9.5% in the second quarter and by nearly 11% for the first half. Our c
componenttext:
Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Altria group delivered strong 2016 second quarter and first half results, growing adjusted diluted earnings per share by 9.5% in the second quarter and by nearly 11% for the first half. 
Our core tobacco businesses continued to produce very strong results, with yet another solid quarter of income and retail share performance. Marlboro matched the record retail share it set in the first half last year, and Copenhagen and Skoal produced excellent share results on a combined basis. And we continued to reward our shareholders, paying out more than $2.2 billion in dividends to shareholders thus far in 2016. 
So here are some of the operating highlights from the quarter and the first half. The smokeable products segment continued to produce excellent results. Despite difficult year-over-year comparisons, it grew adjusted operating company's income by 4.5% in the second quarter and nearly 7% for the first half. You'll recall that last year, the smokable segment grew adjusted OCI by nearly 16% in the second quarter and over 14% for the first half. This growth in 2015 benefited from higher reported volumes at PM USA, driven by stable industry volume and a trade inventory build influenced by upcoming cigarette excise tax increases.  
In the second quarter of 2016, the trade depleted inventory levels. So when adjusted for these inventory movements, PM USA estimates its second quarter cigarette volume declined 3%, in line with PM USA's estimate for the total industry declined rate. For the half, PM USA estimates that its adjusted cigarette volume declined 1.5%, in line with the industry. 
For the first half of 2016, Marlboro's retail share was unchanged at 44.1%, matching its record share levels at a year ago. Marlboro's second quarter retail share also was 44.1%, down 0.1 point form the year-ago period. We are extremely pleased with the smokable segments performance in both the second quarter and first half of 2016. 
Our smokeless products segment continued to deliver excellent income performance, robust volumes and strong share growth on Copenhagen and Skoal combined.  
USSTC grew adjusted OCI by nearly 14% in the second quarter and more than 15% for the first half. USSTC estimates that its volume, after adjusting for trade inventory movements and other factors, grew approximately 5% in the second quarter and 4% for the first half, while estimated smokeless industry volume grew approximately 3% for the past 6 months. 
Copenhagen and Skoal increased their combined retail share by 1.5 points in the second quarter and by 0.9 of 1 share point for the first half. Copenhagen's retail share gained nearly 3 points in the quarter, benefiting from the first full quarter of Copenhagen Mint's national expansion at retail.  Copenhagen Mint has performed extremely well, bringing excitement to the brand for both adult dippers and for the trade. 
Skoal's retail share declined 1.3 points in the second quarter, reflecting in part USSTC's portfolio strategy to invest behind Copenhagen and expand Copenhagen Mint. And as you know, part of USSTC's strategy is to grow the combined share of Copenhagen and Skoal. 
In innovative tobacco products, Nu Mark continues to invest with discipline in developing a portfolio of products to meet the evolving preferences of adult tobacco consumers. In e-vapor, market results for MarkTen XL remain encouraging as Nu Mark has now distributed the brand into stores, representing approximately 50% of e-vapor category volume in mainstream retail channels, including c-stores. 
On the heated tobacco platform, our work with Philip Morris International on its FDA applications, where premarket authorization and a modified risk tobacco product destination remains on plan, and we're making excellent progress on commercialization strategies for the U.S. market. 
As you know, in May, the FDA published its final deeming regulation, expanding it's regulatory authority to all tobacco products, including cigars and e-vapor. We believe we're well-prepared for these regulations and Nu Mark and Middleton are working now to comply with them. Our companies also continued to engage with FDA and other stakeholders to advocate for changes to the regulations where we believe appropriate. 
So in summary, we're very pleased with our first half performance. Based on these results and our expectation that our businesses will deliver solid results over the balance of 2016, we now expect to deliver 2016 adjusted diluted earnings per share in a range of $3.01 to $3.07, representing a growth rate of 7.5% to 9.5% from our 2015 adjusted diluted EPS base of $2.80. As a reminder, this guidance does not include any impact from the proposed AB InBev/SABMiller business combination, as the transaction remains subject to certain approvals and the closing date has not yet been determined. 
Speaking of our beer investment, we're pleased with the significant progress AB InBev has made, securing regulatory clearances. AB InBev has announced that it has obtained approval in 22 jurisdictions, including approvals in the United States, North America, Asia Pacific, Africa, Europe and Latin America. And AB InBev continues to pursue the remaining regulatory clearances that are necessary to close the transaction. 
In addition, as you know, on July 26, AB InBev announced its revised and final offer to SABMiller. This offer, among other things, would increase the pretax cash that Altria expects to receive to $3 billion from the previously estimated $2.5 billion. The other material terms related to Altria remain the same. 
Internally, our teams are preparing to transition our investment from SABMiller to the new combined entity. One such area of preparation is coordinating how our accounting teams will share information. And through this preparation, we now expect a timing difference between how we currently report results for our SABMiller investment and how we'll report for our investment in the new combined company. 
Once the proposed transaction closes, we expect to record our share of results from the new company on a 1-quarter lag. Billy will provide you with more detail in his remarks. We remain excited about the proposed transaction and look forward to supporting the combination of these 2 great companies. 
Now I'll turn things over to Billy for more detail on our performance.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with some more color on the smokable products segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.6 percentage points in the second quarter to over 50%, primarily driven by higher net pricing and lower SG&A co
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with some more color on the smokable products segment. Adjusted OCI margins expanded by 2.6 percentage points in the second quarter to over 50%, primarily driven by higher net pricing and lower SG&A costs, partially offset by higher resolution expenses. For the first half, adjusted OCI margins in the segment expended 2.2 points to 49.2%, primarily driven by the same factors. 
PM USA's reported domestic cigarette shipment volume declined 5% in the second quarter, primarily driven by the industry's rate of decline and trade inventory moments. In the second quarter of last year, the trade built inventory, ahead of excise tax increases in several states that went into effect in the next quarter. For the first half PM USA's reported cigarette shipment volume declined 2.1%. 
At retail, PM USA's overall share was unchanged in the second quarter and grew 0.1 of 1 point for the first half. 
In cigars, higher shipment volume contributed to the smokeable products segment's performance in both periods. Middleton grew Black & Mild's volume by 7.5% in the quarter and nearly 8% for the first half by focusing on the brand strength in the more profitable tip segment. 
In the smokeless products segment, adjusted OCI margins expanded in the second quarter by nearly 3 percentage points to 69.3% and by 2.6 percentage points to 67.5% for the first half, primarily driven by higher net pricing, partially offset by mix due to higher popular price product volume.  The smokeless segment's reported shipment volumes increased 4.3% in the second quarter and 6% for the first half of 2016, primarily driven by the industry's rate of growth and retail share gains. 
In wine, Ste. Michelle continued to deliver strong results by growing volume of its premium wines. During this second quarter and first half, Ste. Michelle grew adjusted OCI by nearly 6% and 5%, respectively.  Ste. Michelle's reported wine shipment volumes grew more than 3% in the second quarter and 5.5% for the first half. 
Altria recorded reported equity earnings from its SABMiller investment of $199 million in the second quarter and $265 million for the first half. 
So let me close with some more information on the accounting of our beer investment that Marty mentioned. For context, Altria currently records results for its SABMiller investment concurrent with Altria's reporting calendar. Because NewCo's results will not be available to us in time to record them in the concurrent period, we expect to report our share of NewCo's results using a 1-quarter lag. This means that after the transaction closes, there will be a one-time, 3-month transition where no earnings from our equity investment in NewCo are recorded in our income statement. For example, Altair's share of NewCo's results in the quarter in which the transaction closes will be recorded in the subsequent quarter. The precise periods affected will depend on when the transaction closes. 
It's important to understand that this lag will not affect our cash flows or quarterly dividends per share, but we do expect it to impact our year-over-year comparability of our reported and adjusted diluted EPS in the short term and could also affect 2016 adjusted diluted EPS guidance. As noted in our earnings release, our guidance does not yet include the impact of the expected lag because the transaction remains subject to certain approvals and the closing date has not yet been determined. 
That wraps our results. Marty and I will now take your questions. While the calls are being compiled, I'll direct your attention to altria.com. Along with today's earnings release, for your reference, we have posted our usual list of quarterly metrics, including pricing, inventory and other housekeeping items. 
Operator, do we have any questions?

Down 3%, a little different from what Reynolds had indicated, but either way, we are moving back towards more of a normalized rate of decline. I know you don't like to guidance on volumes. So in this quarter, with the gas price down, the consumer is still in better shape, it looked like volume is still weak a little bit sequentially more than I expected. Anything you'd offer in relation to that? And if you could speak at all about the second half, that would be great as well.

headline: Altria Group, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chris. Listen, I don't -- we don't see anything in the quarter that causes us to call it out for you. I do think it's consistent with what we've said and you and others I think have said over time that you would expect for the long-term trends to re
componenttext: Sure, Chris. Listen, I don't -- we don't see anything in the quarter that causes us to call it out for you. I do think it's consistent with what we've said and you and others I think have said over time that you would expect for the long-term trends to revert back to their trend line. If you look at '15, we ended the year up 0.5 the quarter before was down 0.5and now for the year, so far, the first half we're down about 1.5. So 1.5 obviously is lower than the long-term trend line, but it's higher than it was in 2015 when we had these interruptions because of the gas prices and all. So I think it's consistent with how we see it Chris, which is, it's just slowly reverting back to the long-term trend line.
